data.title: Rio Tinto dropping Alcan name at new Montreal headquarters
data.meta_description: Rio Tinto says it is dropping the Alcan name to better reflect all the company's services in Montreal
data.text:
Article content

MONTREAL – As Rio Tinto Alcan prepares to move its Montreal offices, the name of the Canadian aluminum subsidiary will be scaled down — including being dropped from the new building’s signage — in order to represent all of the company’s services based in the city.

“It will better reflect the business and the presence that will be under the Rio Tinto banner,” said spokeswoman Claudine Gagnon. “We’re a global business and a global office for Rio Tinto. It’s a cooperative way to see the moving to the new building.”

Article content

Alcan was founded in Montreal in 1902 as the Northern Aluminum Company and in 2007 was acquired by Rio Tinto for US$38 billion.

Recommended from Editorial

Sizing up a potential Glencore-Rio Tinto deal

BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto move to dominate in copper

This fall, Rio Tinto plans to move its Montreal headquarters to the top eight floors of the 26-story Deloitte Tower. Along with the aluminum subsidiary it will also include the Iron Ore Company of Canada; its aluminum and titanium division, RTFT; and its Diavik diamond operations.

Gagnon says Rio Tinto Alcan’s operations will remain unchanged.

“Rio Tinto Alcan is an entity, and will remain an entity,” she said.

The name will remain unchanged for some of the company’s public representation, including Montreal’s Rio Tinto Alcan Planetarium, and the Montreal Jazz Festival.

Gagnon says there are no plans to remove Alcan from any of the signage at aluminum operations across the province.

Rio Tinto is shedding between 110 and 170 jobs in Montreal, as part of the London-based company’s efforts to reduce global costs.

About 800 employees currently work for the aluminum and other metal group divisions in Montreal.
